p: In 2015 there was an outbreak of Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) in Korea resulting in a 20% mortality rate [ 20]. Much like COVID-19, preventive vaccine and treatment options were not clearly established. During the MERS epidemic 80.2% of the general public reported fear of being infected, and 46% reported emotional distress [ 21]. Risk factors associated with the fear among the general public included public transportation use, difficulty going outside, perception that the state is not protecting people, helplessness in situations that cannot be controlled, and fear of infection [ 21]. In many ways the nature of the MERS epidemic was similar to the COVID-19 pandemic in the sense that fear of being infected and many of the risk factors contributing to that fear are felt today.
